bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, August 30, 1954

div1.p: Hench sends Lawrence Reed a list of questions regarding the specific characteristics of his father.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, August 30, 1954
div1.opener:
August 30, 1954
General Walter L. Reed
2810 - 36th Place, N.W.
Washington 7, D. C.
My dear General Reed:
div1.p:
I have had a very nice letter from your good wife saying that she is off
to England and telling me that she will return my medal on her return
even though you have not yet gotten yours back. General Reed, I don't
want mine back until you get yours. There is absolutely no hurry about
this and I want you to keep mine as long as you need it.

The next time I come to Washington, I want to ask you a few more questions
about your father. Perhaps you could be thinking these over.

1. I want to know his height. On my last visit, you stated you thought he
was 5′ 11″ - Miss Blossom thought he was 6 feet. His weight was around
150 to 156. He had dark brown hair, sprinkled with grey, blue eyes and a
“Chinaman's moustache”.

2. As you know, he has been written up in such hallowed terms that, ac-
cording to some writers, he was almost a god and not human. I am sure
you would not have me portray him in that manner. One of the Cuban nurses
wrote that your father, one time at the mess at the post hospital, Camp
Columbia, got up and walked out because a couple of his younger officers
used profanity. I have no doubt your father knew that there was a time and place
for the milder type of profanity, and that he would be intolerant of a cer-
tain type of profanity, especially of smut, but I can't picture your father
as being a prude and, if my memory serves me correctly, in some of his letters
to very close friends, he occasionally used the word “damn” very effectively.
I should like to ask you about this side of his personality and, as I under-
stand him, while he had an air of great dignity, he was not unapproachable,
and in the bosom of friends he was even gay. From incidents that have oc-
curred I know, too, that he had a subtle humor and some whimsey and of
course from his letters to his family, it is obvious that in the bosom of
those whom he loved so much, he was a doting father, a tender and worshiping
husband and threw all reserve to the winds.

As I understand it, he was on very good terms of friendship (though not a
first name caller) with his medical colleagues of all ages, from General
Kean to Lt. Truby, more reserved with other medical officers whom he called
“doctor” rather than by their military rank, and quite dignified with soldiers
and strangers in general. Though dignified and reserved, I believe he was
approachable and friendly to any soldier whose reason for conversation with
him was valid.
General Walter L. Reed - 2 - August 30, 1954

3. Can you tell me a little of his sense of humor? I have numerous
incidents upon which to base my own opinion but would like your own.

4. What was his attitude on liquor? I believe he drank socially. Did
he have any firm rules for himself and others?
5. Did he smoke?
6. What were his chief recreations? I seem to have little data on this.

7. Did he like the theater? If so, what type - vandeville, musical
comedy, operettas, drama, farce?
8. What were his hobbies and antipathies?

9. Did he like the company of men and women? He certainly was entirely
sociable but was he sociable enough to enjoy going to an evening affair where
only relative strangers or acquaintances were present? Did he enjoy the
company of women friends? What was his favorite type of man?

10. What were his clothing habits? In the pictures I have seen of him he
was meticulously dressed whether in uniform or civilian clothes. Did he
ever unbend and wear lounging clothes?

11. Did he work in the garden much at Blue Ridge Summit? How did he oc-
cupy his time at Blue Ridge Summit?

12. What kind of a reader was he - an avid reader? What kind of books
did he like most?

13. What were his ambitions, primary and secondary? Of course in his
famous New Year's letter to your mother, he expressed his deep satisfac-
tion for having fulfilled his ambition to serve humanity through medicine.
Did he ever discuss with you his ambitions in less spiritual terms? Fate
made him, certainly in his later years, more the researcher than the
medical practitioner. Did he do research from a sense of duty or with a
burning desire, and do you think that medical research - the typhoid in-
vestigation, the yellow fever investigation (bacteriology in general), was
his main ambition and the practice of medicine secondary, or did he actually
enjoy practicing Army medicine? Certainly he must have been willing to
lower his financial ambitions, if any, when he decided to stay in the Army.
Certainly he had compensations in lieu of finances. Did he ever discuss
this matter with you?

14. What was his attitude on religion? His personal attitude? His
formal attitude? Obviously he was deeply spiritual but was he also
strongly interested in formalized religion? Of course I know the ministerial
background of the family.
General Walter L. Reed - 3 - August 30, 1954

Of these things I should like to talk to you more and if, between now and
when we meet you should have the ambition to jot down a few words, we
could amplify them by a little “interview” later. Would you be willing
to have me ask my former secretary in Washington, Miss Dorma Schnurr, to
come over for an hour every now and then, completely at your convenience,
so that she could take down your answers to these questions and in that
way, you wouldn't have to write a note and I could send Miss Schnurr a
copy of these questions ahead of time so that she could familiarize herself
with them and save for you as much of your time as possible.
